stream_context.summary: The stream focused on implementing and refining the visuals for the game's overworld. The primary task was creating a dynamic water effect that simulates waves flowing towards the central island, which involved significant experimentation with shaders, vertex manipulation, and debugging. Kaze also briefly worked on selecting wood textures for a dock and discussed the overall color palette.

development_findings.summary: While looking for inspiration, Kaze heavily criticized the water effects in 'The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker' as being too simple, revealing his high technical and aesthetic standards for his own project.
development_findings.quote: This looks so bad. This looks so dumb... I am not okay with this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze successfully developed a custom water shader that creates the illusion of waves moving towards the island by dynamically manipulating vertex height, color, and mesh curvature, solving a major visual and technical challenge.
development_findings.quote: Now the waves actually look properly going into the island. It looks very tropical.

development_findings.summary: Kaze considered replacing standard wooden support pillars for a dock with something more playful like rubber duckies, showing his design process prioritizes a fun, whimsical aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: maybe floaties are more playful, maybe we have a fun idea for floaties.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses a common graphics technique of layering a noise texture over repeating textures to mask tiling and create a more organic look.
development_findings.quote: I added a noise texture on top of it, so that it doesn't tile obviously.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to add foam effects to the shoreline by mapping a texture to vertices and controlling its opacity based on the calculated height of the wave at that point.
The project is targeting a 64-megabyte ROM size, utilizing the maximum capacity of official N64 cartridges, rather than a more limited size.
development_findings.quote: I'm not going with an 8 megabyte game, I'm going with 64 megabytes.

development_findings.summary: A crash during development was traced back to the game's engine trying to process collision for too many triangles in the initial water mesh, not the new wave logic Kaze had written.

context_findings.summary: Kaze spent the last week rewriting the entire Mario 64 audio engine to improve efficiency, debuggability, and to make it legally distinct from Nintendo's original code for a potential future release.
context_findings.quote: I spent a lot of time completely rewriting Mario 64's audio engine... It's also all my own code now... I think we're fine legally to just use this in our own game now.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on the history of the Mario 64 hacking scene, acknowledging that for a long time it was not well-regarded within the broader console homebrew community.
context_findings.quote: for the longest time the Mari64 community was like such a pathetic part of the homebrew community.

context_findings.summary: When asked about the motivation behind the project, Kaze states his reasoning was simply his fondness for the character Yoshi, indicating a passion-driven origin.
context_findings.quote: I like Yoshi. That's kind of where the thought process ended.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with receiving negative or nonsensical comments on his YouTube videos, highlighting a downside of being a public creator.
context_findings.quote: I'm getting so many nonsense comments this is the worst part about making a video.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his personal life, noting that he unintentionally lost a significant amount of weight recently.
context_findings.quote: I was actually down to 195 pounds today, this morning... from, like, 215. And it's an accident, I didn't mean to lose weight, but I just lost 20 pounds.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shares a brief, personal anecdote about his infant daughter.
context_findings.quote: My baby's favorite thing, she's like almost nine months now, is eating the remote.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time feedback or suggestions in chat regarding the water effects, to which Kaze responded with his technical and gameplay concerns, demonstrating their collaborative process.
biobak.quote: Yeah, I mean we can do that Biobak, but what about swimming in it? That's what I'm worried about.

key_stories.title: The Quest for Perfect Water
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a high-quality water effect for the overworld. After exploring and rejecting various options, he iteratively built a custom solution from a simple sine wave into a complex, dynamic effect that creates the illusion of tropical waves flowing towards the island, solving both a technical and artistic problem live on stream.
key_stories.challenge: Create a convincing, dynamic water effect for the overworld that looks like waves flowing towards the shore, works on N64 hardware, and doesn't interfere with swimming gameplay.
key_stories.process: Kaze first dismissed complex methods like Gerstner waves as too performance-heavy and rejected simpler effects from games like Wind Waker as visually inadequate. He implemented a basic sine wave system, debugged a crash caused by excessive collision triangles, and then iteratively improved the effect by adding dynamic vertex coloring for depth, adjusting wave parameters, making waves smaller near the shore, and adding a curve to the mesh to perfect the illusion of inward-flowing waves.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a custom solution using a sine wave function that modifies vertex height and color based on distance from the island's center. The result is a performant and visually pleasing ocean effect that meets his goals, with plans for further refinement like adding foam.
key_stories.key_quote: Now the waves actually look properly going into the island. It looks very tropical. That's good. And all you need is one or two good RSP state setups, a.k.a. not shaders.

key_stories.title: Rewriting History: The Audio Engine
key_stories.summary: To improve the game's foundation and address potential legal issues, Kaze undertook the significant task of completely rewriting the Mario 64 audio engine. This effort resulted in a more efficient, debuggable, and proprietary system, moving the project closer to being a truly standalone game.
key_stories.challenge: The original Mario 64 audio engine was inefficient, difficult to debug, and posed a legal obstacle to potentially releasing the project as an original game.
key_stories.process: Kaze dedicated a full week to rewriting the audio engine from the ground up. This involved replacing Nintendo's original code with his own, leaving only the low-level interface to the N64's Reality Signal Processor (RSP) intact for now.
key_stories.outcome: The project now has a custom, modern audio engine that is more memory-efficient, easier to debug, and legally distinct from Nintendo's code. This improves the project's technical foundation and clears a path for a potential original release.
key_stories.key_quote: I spent a lot of time completely rewriting Mario 64's audio engine... And now I understand the whole codebase. Meaning it's going to be very easy to debug any problems that may occur.
